newsitem.title: TURKEY: Car bomb blast in Turkish Islamist escape bid.
newsitem.headline: Car bomb blast in Turkish Islamist escape bid.

text.p: A car bomb exploded in central Turkey on Friday in an apparent attempt to free eight Islamist convicts being carried to court in an armoured prison vehicle, Anatolian news agency said.

It said three gendarmerie police and an inmate were wounded in the attack in the arid province of Kirsehir. Other gendarmes sealed off the area and prevented the suspects from escaping, the state-run agency said.
"A bomb loaded into a car at the side of the road was set off by remote control...as the armoured prison vehicle was going past," Anatolian quoted local official Osman Gurbuz as saying.
The prisoners face the death sentence on charges of forming an armed group with the intention of changing Turkey's secularist constitution.
They were being taken to Ankara for a retrial in their case, related to the killing of 37 people, most of them members of a liberal, heterodox Moslem sect, in an Islamist arson attack in 1993.
Turkish courts sometimes issue death sentences although no one has been executed in Turkey since the early 1980s.
The eight were among 41 people originally sentenced to 15 years each for the arson attack, in the city of Sivas. The appeals court later called for retrials and tougher sentences.
Police stepped up security measures near mosques throughout Turkey to prevent expected Islamist protests after Friday noon prayers at government plans to curb religious education.

Witnesses said police armoured cars took up position at key spots in the centre of Ankara. Uniformed and plainclothes police milled around outside the Grand Mosque in Diyarbakir, the main city in the mainly Kurdish southeast.
Police on Tuesday detained more than 50 people at a large Islamist rally in Ankara that turned violent.
Islamist anger at Turkey's secularist establishment has risen since Islamist Pime Minister Necmettin Erbakan resigned under military pressure in June.
He was replaced by secularist Mesut Yilmaz who has vowed to carry out a key military demand to restrict the scope of Islamic schools.
